content:
lass="word-wrap-span">OVER lass="word-wrap-span">HALF a century ago, lass="word-wrap-span">Congress struck a blow for gender equality when it passed lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Civil lass="word-wrap-span">Rights lass="word-wrap-span">Act of 1964. lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII of that law, which made it illegal for employers to lass="word-wrap-span">discriminate “because of sex”, has been lass="word-wrap-span">interpreted to uphold lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Rights of women to be hired for a so-called “man’s job”; to get promotions without having to wear make-up or behave “more lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">femininely”; to work in offices where lass="word-wrap-span">Sexual favours are not an lass="word-wrap-span">implicit job requirement; and not to be passed lass="word-wrap-span">OVER for a position because lass="word-wrap-span">They have young children. lass="word-wrap-span">The courts have read lass="word-wrap-span">The law to protect men, too. lass="word-wrap-span">Sexual lass="word-wrap-span">harassment of male employees counts as sex-lass="word-wrap-span">based lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination even if lass="word-wrap-span">Congress was not contemplating that particular scourge when drafting lass="word-wrap-span">The law.

lass="word-wrap-span">Two more facets of workplass="word-wrap-span">lace mistreatment, and flashpoints in lass="word-wrap-span">The culture wars, will come before lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court in a pair of oral arguments on lass="word-wrap-span">October 8th. lass="word-wrap-span">Does lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII’s prohibition on sex lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination protect gay and lesbian people from being lass="word-wrap-span">fired on lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">basis of lass="word-wrap-span">Their sexual orientation? lass="word-wrap-span">Does it safeguard transgender workers from similar bias? lass="word-wrap-span">The briefs for lass="word-wrap-span">The plaintiffs in lass="word-wrap-span">Altitude lass="word-wrap-span">Express, lass="word-wrap-span">Inc. v Zarda , Bostock v lass="word-wrap-span">Clayton lass="word-wrap-span">County, Georgia and R.G. & G.R. lass="word-wrap-span">Harris lass="word-wrap-span">Funeral lass="word-wrap-span">Homes lass="word-wrap-span">Inc. v lass="word-wrap-span">Equal lass="word-wrap-span">Employment lass="word-wrap-span">Opportunity lass="word-wrap-span">Commission are in—and lass="word-wrap-span">They are persuasive.

lass="word-wrap-span">The inlass="word-wrap-span">dividuals at lass="word-wrap-span">The centre of lass="word-wrap-span">The cases are lass="word-wrap-span">Gerald Bostock, a social worker in Georgia who was sacked after joining a gay softball league; lass="word-wrap-span">Donald Zarda, a sky-lass="word-wrap-span">diving lass="word-wrap-span">instructor in lass="word-wrap-span">New York whose sexual orientation also cost him his job (he has since died); and lass="word-wrap-span">Aimee Stephlass="word-wrap-span">ens, an lass="word-wrap-span">embalmer whose presentation as a transgender woman led to her lass="word-wrap-span">dismissal from her position at a lass="word-wrap-span">funeral home in lass="word-wrap-span">Michigan. Mr Zarda and Ms Stephlass="word-wrap-span">ens won lass="word-wrap-span">Their cases in lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Second and lass="word-wrap-span">Sixth lass="word-wrap-span">Circuit lass="word-wrap-span">Courts of lass="word-wrap-span">Appeals, respectively, while Mr Bostock lost his bid at lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Eleventh lass="word-wrap-span">Circuit.

lass="word-wrap-span">The loss in Bostock was not a particular surprise, as lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Eleventh lass="word-wrap-span">Circuit has shifted to lass="word-wrap-span">The right with three recent judicial lass="word-wrap-span">appointments by lass="word-wrap-span">Preslass="word-wrap-span">ident lass="word-wrap-span">Donald lass="word-wrap-span">Trump. lass="word-wrap-span">But lass="word-wrap-span">The analysis in lass="word-wrap-span">The published opinion was remarkable for its dismissiveness. Mr Bostock’s lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination complaint, lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Court ruled, was lass="word-wrap-span">invalid under a lass="word-wrap-span">Circuit-lass="word-wrap-span">Court decision from 1979. lass="word-wrap-span">Yet that case, lass="word-wrap-span">Blum v lass="word-wrap-span">Gulf lass="word-wrap-span">Oil Corp. , arrived nearly a decade before lass="word-wrap-span">Price lass="word-wrap-span">Waterhouse v lass="word-wrap-span">Hopkins , a 6-3 lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court decision siding with a female employee who had been denied a promotion for failing to lass="word-wrap-span">adhere to stereotypically lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">feminine norms of appearance and behaviour. lass="word-wrap-span">When lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">Eleventh lass="word-wrap-span">Circuit voted 9-2 against reconslass="word-wrap-span">idering Mr Bostock's complaint “en banc” (as a full lass="word-wrap-span">Court), lass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">dissenters were lass="word-wrap-span">incredulous . lass="word-wrap-span">They could not grasp “why a majority of our lass="word-wrap-span">Court is lass="word-wrap-span">content to rely on lass="word-wrap-span">The precedential lass="word-wrap-span">equivalent of an lass="word-wrap-span">Edsel with a missing engine" with lass="word-wrap-span">The rights of “so many people” at stake.

Explass="word-wrap-span">Anding gay rights via an old statute might seem like a stretch for a lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court with a five-lass="word-wrap-span">Justice lass="word-wrap-span">conservative majority that now lass="word-wrap-span">lacks lass="word-wrap-span">Justice lass="word-wrap-span">Anthony Kennedy, who authored four llass="word-wrap-span">Andmark opinions vindicating the rights of gay lass="word-wrap-span">And lesbian people. It may be. lass="word-wrap-span">But the most promising arguments running through four dozen briefs from the plaintiffs lass="word-wrap-span">And their supporters do not try to push the lass="word-wrap-span">Justices toward any particularly radical lass="word-wrap-span">ideas. No newfangled rendering of lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII is necessary to find for the LGBT plaintiffs, the briefs say. lass="word-wrap-span">Even if the lass="word-wrap-span">Courts stick to the lass="word-wrap-span">conception of “sex” as lass="word-wrap-span">anchored by biology lass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">genetics (with no gestures toward social roles or queer theory), the gay lass="word-wrap-span">And trans workers should win. lass="word-wrap-span">And the briefs—including the one filed by Ms Stephlass="word-wrap-span">ens’s lawyers —wisely stick to the lass="word-wrap-span">conservative lass="word-wrap-span">Justices’ favoured method of lass="word-wrap-span">interpreting statutes: textualism, which conslass="word-wrap-span">iders how a law is written, rather than how its lass="word-wrap-span">drafters imagined it would be applied.

In a brief prepared for several former solilass="word-wrap-span">Citors general, lass="word-wrap-span">Joshua Matz, a lawyer in lass="word-wrap-span">New York, and lass="word-wrap-span">Laurence lass="word-wrap-span">Tribe, a Harvard law professor, begin by reminding the lass="word-wrap-span">Court that the meaning of a law “is distlass="word-wrap-span">Inct from how people may have expected the statute would apply when it was lass="word-wrap-span">enacted”. lass="word-wrap-span">Citing Oncale v lass="word-wrap-span">Sundowner lass="word-wrap-span">Offshore lass="word-wrap-span">Services, lass="word-wrap-span">Inc. —a 1998 lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court decision recognising that lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII bars sexual lass="word-wrap-span">harassment of male employees—the authors recall the late lass="word-wrap-span">Justice lass="word-wrap-span">Antonin Scalia’s lass="word-wrap-span">clarion call to textualism: “it is ultimately our laws rather than the prlass="word-wrap-span">Incipal concerns of our legislators by which we are governed”.

lass="word-wrap-span">The brief lass="word-wrap-span">Then turns to lass="word-wrap-span">The “plain text” of lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII and observes how it protects LGBT people. It’s not necessarily because “sex” means “sexual orientation” or “gender lass="word-wrap-span">identity”, lass="word-wrap-span">The brief argues, but because an employer logically cannot lass="word-wrap-span">fire someone on one of lass="word-wrap-span">These lass="word-wrap-span">bases without paying close attention to lass="word-wrap-span">Their perceived or actual sex, and applying stereotypes governing how people of that sex should present lass="word-wrap-span">Themselves or whom lass="word-wrap-span">They should be attracted to. lass="word-wrap-span">When you lass="word-wrap-span">fire someone for being transgender, lass="word-wrap-span">The brief reasons, you are saying lass="word-wrap-span">They should behave and dress in ways that match standards attached to lass="word-wrap-span">Their lass="word-wrap-span">biological sex. lass="word-wrap-span">When you lass="word-wrap-span">fire an employee for being gay, you are saying lass="word-wrap-span">Their sex lass="word-wrap-span">dictates a particular object of romantic interest. lass="word-wrap-span">Neilass="word-wrap-span">Ther lass="word-wrap-span">dismissal would have occurred had lass="word-wrap-span">The employee been born to lass="word-wrap-span">The opposite lass="word-wrap-span">biological sex, or absent lass="word-wrap-span">The stereotypes harboured by lass="word-wrap-span">The employer. lass="word-wrap-span">Both lass="word-wrap-span">firings, lass="word-wrap-span">Messrs Matz and lass="word-wrap-span">Tribe conclude, are lass="word-wrap-span">Therefore lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination “because of sex”.

A similar path to victory for Ms Stephlass="word-wrap-span">ens is outlined in a brief by several law professors . lass="word-wrap-span">The court need lass="word-wrap-span">Not resolve whelass="word-wrap-span">Ther transgender status is itself a protected lass="word-wrap-span">category under lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII, lass="word-wrap-span">The filing reads. It must only take account of lass="word-wrap-span">The facts of lass="word-wrap-span">The case and apply lass="word-wrap-span">Price lass="word-wrap-span">Waterhouse , which bars employers from drawing upon sex-lass="word-wrap-span">based stereotypes when making hiring and lass="word-wrap-span">firing decisions. Ms Stephlass="word-wrap-span">ens was sacked “because she planned to lass="word-wrap-span">disregard certain workplass="word-wrap-span">lace norms” that her boss “imposed only upon lass="word-wrap-span">funeral directors whom he conslass="word-wrap-span">idered to be ‘men’”. lass="word-wrap-span">This is lass="word-wrap-span">analytically lass="word-wrap-span">indistinguishable from a woman being too masculine for a promotion, or a job being too manly for a woman. lass="word-wrap-span">The brief also addresses lass="word-wrap-span">The respondents’ lass="word-wrap-span">contention that a win for lass="word-wrap-span">The plaintiffs would prevent an “employer from having separate men’s and women’s toilet facilities”. lass="word-wrap-span">Not so, lass="word-wrap-span">The scholars respond: separate bathrooms do lass="word-wrap-span">Not impose “severe harms” on employees. lass="word-wrap-span">Fears of a “purge of sex-segregated restrooms across lass="word-wrap-span">The nation are lass="word-wrap-span">Therefore lass="word-wrap-span">declass="word-wrap-span">idedly lass="word-wrap-span">exaggerated”.

If some of the lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court justices opt to conduct a more searching investigation of how “sex” was understood the 1960s, they will find the plaintiffs’ claims have even greater lass="word-wrap-span">credence. An illuminating brief from a group of historians shows that the public’s understanding of sexual lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination in the civil-rights era was “sufficiently broad and multidimlass="word-wrap-span">ensional” to include lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination against LGBT inlass="word-wrap-span">dividuals. lass="word-wrap-span">Battles against sex lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination were waged, in part, to enable “men and women to depart from conventional norms of masculinity and lass="word-wrap-span">femininity, then called ‘sex roles’, without suffering lass="word-wrap-span">detrimental employment lass="word-wrap-span">consequences”. A brief filed by 206 businesses —including lass="word-wrap-span">Amazon, Google, Uber and lass="word-wrap-span">Wells lass="word-wrap-span">Fargo—says LBGT inlass="word-wrap-span">dividuals’ protection from lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination would boost innovation, lass="word-wrap-span">diversify the workforce and increase productivity.

lass="word-wrap-span">Few lawmakers may have had anti-gay and anti-trans lass="word-wrap-span">discrimination in mind 55 years ago when they passed the lass="word-wrap-span">Civil lass="word-wrap-span">Rights lass="word-wrap-span">Act. lass="word-wrap-span">But the language they lass="word-wrap-span">approved is sweeping, and on a lass="word-wrap-span">Court that emphasises a statute’s words—the text itself, not lass="word-wrap-span">Congress’s purposes or expectations—chances of a new lass="word-wrap-span">horizon for lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII seem favourable. If the lass="word-wrap-span">Supreme lass="word-wrap-span">Court ends up expanding the lass="word-wrap-span">Title lass="word-wrap-span">VII umbrella to protect some 10m lass="word-wrap-span">Americans from having their gender lass="word-wrap-span">identity or sexual orientation serve as the lass="word-wrap-span">basis of lass="word-wrap-span">discriminatory treatment, the lass="word-wrap-span">jurisprudential path could be paved not in radical redefinitions of contested lass="word-wrap-span">concepts lass="word-wrap-span">But in syllogisms rooted in well-grounded premises.
